content.content: Recently, I’ve been spending less time keeping up on what’s going on at Maker, and find myself in the position of not knowing what the HVB collateral is. Given my level of involvement up to this point, if I don’t really know what HVB is, it’s fairly likely that most DAI holders don’t know what it is either, and this could well be true for a number of DAI’s backing assets, both on-chain and off-chain. What would be ideal for me and users of DAI (and others besides) would be a simple and concise description of the various assets backing DAI. I’ve decided to coordinate such an initiative, and produce human and machine readable documentation that can be included in various resources, such as the Maker Operational Manual, and frontends like Makerburn. This documentation would include a sentence and paragraph summary of each collateral alongside a URL linking to more information. It would be really useful if those who are more in the know such as members of @collateral-core-unit and @Real-World-Finance could share a succinct explanation for some of the assets listed below. Alternatively, if the asset originators themselves want to comment, please feel free. I’m going for a pretty basic level of explanation here, so if possible, breaking down credit tenant leases / commercial loans / fix and flips to a more everyday and finance illiterate level would be useful. If you don’t have time to write a description, resource links would also be appreciated. These are the assets I’d appreciate help with.  NS-DROP RWA001 / 6s FFT1-DROP HTC-DROP CF-DROP HVBank  Thank you! (@mrabino1 / @g_dip / @spin / @prankstr25 feel free to comment, but no obligation, apologies if I’ve missed anyone that would have appreciated inclusion ) Edit: Apparently RWF is just Will now. So @christiancdpetersen @teej @eumenes get a ping too.

content.content: TLDR for HVBank: HVBank is a US, publicly traded commercial bank with a diversified portfolio of loans spanning the Philly/Pennsylvania area. It’s what’s known as a “community bank” because it is on the ground originating loans within a relatively small region. Community banks are the unsung heroes of the US economy. in my opinion, as they help small businesses to grow and prosper. The way this facility works is quite simple. Maker funds a Delaware Trust with dollars (Dai is converted to dollars upon minting) and this Trust is authorized via pre-written agreements (that can only be amended by a MKR vote) to purchase loans from HVBank. While the Dai is not explicitly backed by these loans, i.e. Dai holders will never find themselves holding a piece of a loan in an ES, it is supported by the value in these loans as they can be sold or allowed to mature at any time to repay the Dai to the Vault.
